required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: ٍٍSofosbuvir/Simeprevir/Daclatasvir/Ribavirin and HCV Genotype 4-infected Egyptian Experienced Participants
clinical_study.official_title: A Sofosbuvir-based Quadruple Regimen is Highly Effective in HCV Type 4-infected Egyptian Patients With DAA Treatment Failure

brief_summary.textblock: Experienced participants who had HCV GT4 infection were treated with Sofosbuvir/Simeprevir/Daclatasvir/Ribavirin (SOF/SMV/DCV/RBV)

detailed_description.textblock:
Experienced participants, who had chronic infection with HCV GT4 , and failed prior DAA treatments, SOF/DCV (71/92) or SOF/SMV (15/92) or SOF/pegylated interferon/RBV (2/92) or SOF/RBV (4/92) were enrolled in the current study.
In the present study, the regimen used was designed by the combination of triple DAAs with different mechanisms of action and non-overlapping resistance profiles, SOF/SMV/DCV, plus RBV.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Sustained Virologic Response 12 Weeks Post-treatment (SVR12) in Each Treatment Arm
primary_outcome.description: SVR12 is defined as hepatitis C virus ribonucleic acid (HCV RNA) level < 15 IU/m 12 weeks after the last dose of drugs.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events in Each Treatment Arm
primary_outcome.time_frame: Screening up to 12 weeks after last dose
primary_outcome.description: An adverse event (AE) is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a participant clinical investigation after administering a pharmaceutical drugs Serious adverse event (SAE) is an event that results in death, life-threatening, requires hospitalization, or significant disability/incapacity

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Viral relapse
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 12 weeks after last dose
secondary_outcome.description: Viral relapse was HCV RNA level undetectable at End of Treatment (EOT) (≤ 15 IU/ml), but detectable HCV RNA ( > 15 IU/ml) levels 12 weeks after planned EOT.

arm_group.description: SOF plus DCV/SMV/RBV regimen was administered to Egyptian non-cirrhotic experienced HCV GT4 participants for 12 weeks
SOF plus DCV/SMV/RBV regimen was administered to Egyptian cirrhotic experienced HCV GT4 participants for 12 weeks

intervention.description: SOF was given orally at a dose of 400 mg/day DCV was given orally at a dose of 60 mg/day SMV was given orally at a dose of 150 mg/day. RBV was given in a total daily oral dose of 600 mg/day up to 1,200 mg/day according to the participant's weight and tolerability.
intervention.other_name: Olysio is a trade name of simeprevir
Sovaldi is a trade name of sofosbuvir
Daklinza is a trade name of daclatasvir

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Experienced Egyptian participants with HCV GT4 infection who had failed prior DAA treatments [SOF/DCV or SOF/SMV or SOF/pegylated interferon/RBV or SOF/RBV]
- Fibrosis-4 score in non-cirrhotic participants is <1.45-3.25: (None or moderate fibrosis)
- Fibrosis-4 score in cirrhotic participants is >3.25: (Advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis)
Exclusion Criteria:
- HCV coinfected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) or human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
- had any liver disease other than chronic HCV GT4 infection.
- had a history of liver decompensation
- serum a-fetoprotein (AFP) > 100 ng/ml
- evidence of hepatocellular carcinoma
- major severe illness such as respiratory, renal, heart failure or autoimmune disease
- non-compliance with treatment.

overall_official.affiliation: Biochemistry Dep., Faculty of Science, Beni-Suef University, P.O. Box 52621

link.description: This link shows the investigation performed in the retreatment with SOF plus DCV/SMV/RBV regimen in EgyptianHCV GT4 participants

results_reference.citation: Abdel-Moneim A, Aboud A, Abdel-Gabbar M, Zanaty MI, Ramadan M. A sofosbuvir-based quadruple regimen is highly effective in HCV type 4-infected Egyptian patients with DAA treatment failure. J Hepatol. 2018 Jun;68(6):1313-1315. doi: 10.1016/j.jhep.2018.03.010. Epub 2018 Apr 3.
